title: Coronation Street spoilers: Rob Mallard reveals that Sinead's death will change Daniel
text:
Daniel Osbourne (Rob Mallard) has been through hell this past year in Coronation Street, what with wife Sinead Tinker (Katie McGlynn) having been diagnosed with terminal cancer, and — in the coming episodes — Sinead bids farewell to her friends and family before passing away — and Daniel will find himself in a brave new world without the love of his life as a result.

Sinead’s battle with cancer last year proved incredibly difficult not only for her, but also for boyfriend Daniel, who remained with her every step of the way. The pair were all set to start a new life together with son Bertie, as they tied the knot in an emotional ceremony earlier this year, but their world came crashing down once more when Sinead was informed that her cancer had returned and that, this time, it was terminal.

After bidding farewell to her friends and family, a series of emotional episodes will see Sinead pass away at the end of next week. With Sinead having been the love of Daniel’s life, having to say goodbye will no doubt be an incredibly difficult task for the young man, so how will be cope following her death?

Actor Rob Mallard said: ‘There’s been a foreshadowing of the self-destructive element, you’ll see that first. The snap of the elastic, can’t expect him to keep it together straight away. He has Bertie to focus on, but that’s the next stage of the story – Sinead has told him all these things, forgive himself and all of that, but it’s all caught up in the death.’

‘He now has to unpick all of that, the meaning and the message of what she said and actually apply it. But with the trauma and shock, you get away from that as quickly as possible. There will be changes in Daniel, but may take a bit of time to implement it.’

Although Sinead’s life will come to an end, this isn’t the end of the story as — much like in real-life — her close friends and family will have to come to terms with life without her, and for Daniel it’ll be particularly difficult, as — in addition to mourning the love of his life — he’ll also be faced with the fact that he now has to raise Bertie on his own.

Rob said: ‘It’s a continuation. There’s two parts – there’s that part to the story, and then it moves into the people who’ve been left behind.’

‘Before Sinead, he was completely self-motivated and concentrated on survival, because he’d been on his own for ages. I think even though he’ll try to be stoic for the sake of the baby, you can’t suppress the worst parts of your personality. The nastiness, the bitchiness and moaning that he’s very good at.’

‘He doesn’t want to do that because of the kid and the promise that he made, but it’ll probably seep into everywhere else and go onto other characters. We’ve filmed stuff like that. They’ll get his bad moods because he can’t do it to the kids.’

On Daniel’s reaction to Sinead’s death, Corrie’s Executive Producer, Iain MacLeod said: ‘The early phase of this story is that Daniel’s is so obsessively taking care of Bertie that he’s neglecting himself because he feels like the promise he made to Sinead was to look after Bertie and never let him down, but he fails to appreciate that if you’re not looking after yourself, then that in its own way is still letting down your son.
